persona.name: Riley Ajani

occupation.title: University Student / Freelance Social Media Assistant
occupation.organization: University of Lagos (student) / freelance with small online clients
occupation.description: Riley is a full-time undergraduate Media & Communications student (economically inactive as a student). They supplement studies with irregular freelance work: managing Instagram accounts for two local cafés, editing short promotional videos for an online clothing seller, and helping a nearby NGO with basic social-media fundraising campaigns. Responsibilities include attending lectures and tutorials, producing short documentary assignments, shooting and editing short video content on a smartphone, caption-writing in English and Nigerian Pidgin, scheduling posts, responding to community messages, and occasionally helping set up live streams. They are learning to balance course deadlines with paid gigs and are developing skills in basic budgeting, pitching content, and client communication. Their primary difficulties are inconsistent income, unreliable electricity while editing at home, and navigating university bureaucracy for scholarship/stipend applications.

persona.education: Completed Nigerian Senior Secondary Certificate (WAEC) at a public urban school with strong arts and media extracurriculars. Currently enrolled as a first-year undergraduate at the University of Lagos, Faculty of Arts, studying Media and Communications (freshman). Took supplementary online courses in basic video editing, social media marketing, and introductory coding over the last year.
long_term_goals: Build a sustainable career in media production and content strategy that allows creative freedom and stable income.
Start a small multimedia studio that produces short documentaries and branded content for local businesses and NGOs.
Be financially independent and support immediate family members when needed.
Help create safer, visible spaces for gender diverse young people in their community.
Travel to at least five countries for study, work, or cultural exchange before turning 30.
Finish an entrepreneurial course and learn basic accounting to run a small business responsibly.
Mentor younger students from their neighborhood in digital skills and media literacy.
Document and archive local cultural stories from Lagos neighborhoods and markets.
Develop a recognizable personal brand on streaming and social platforms known for quality storytelling.
Maintain a healthy balance between activism, creativity, and everyday life so burnout doesn’t derail the plan.
persona.style: Casual, conversational, and digitally-native. Speaks Nigerian English with frequent quick switches into Yoruba and Nigerian Pidgin depending on the listener; comfortable using Lagos slang and internet shorthand (e.g., 'abi', 'no wahala', emojis). When nervous, Riley laughs softly and fingers the hem of their hoodie; when animated they gesture with both hands and lean forward, eyes bright. Usually speaks in short, clipped sentences on new topics but stretches into long, detailed stories when engaged. Uses polite forms with elders but quickly adopts informal tones with peers. Prefers layered, street-smart fashion: oversized hoodie or bomber jacket, thrifted tees, high-top trainers, simple silver hoops, and a crossbody bag where they keep earbuds and a portable power bank. Often uses humor and self-deprecation to defuse tension. Comfortable on camera; practices 'talking to viewer' cadence learned from influencers. Likes to use concise, punchy catchphrases in captions. In writing, Riley favors clear, image-rich descriptions and frequently uses GIFs and memes to communicate tone. Has a habit of ending messages with a small emoji to soften direct requests. Prefers to be addressed with they/them pronouns in formal and informal settings, but will correct gently if someone slips up.

traits: Curious and exploratory: has a strong appetite for new media formats and cultural trends.
Adaptable: handles shifting schedules and the chaos of Lagos urban life with pragmatic improvisation.
Warm and approachable in small groups; guarded with strangers.
Determined: when invested in a project, Riley can become obsessively focused for days.
Sensitive to criticism: internalizes feedback and may ruminate before responding.
Playful sense of humor: uses irony and pop-culture references as social glue.
Socially conscious: cares about fairness, representation, and local community issues.
Perfectionist about creative output: will re-edit a video multiple times to get pacing right.
Procrastinates on administrative tasks (e.g., scholarship forms) but meets deadlines for creative deliverables more reliably.
Empathetic listener, often the friend people confide in, but sometimes struggles to set boundaries.
Resourceful: finds low-cost ways to solve technical problems, like shooting with ambient light or borrowing kit.
Restless: dislikes long stretches of monotony and seeks stimulation through short projects or events.

big_five.openness: High (8/10). Very curious about art, culture, new platforms, and ideas; enjoys experimenting with formats.
big_five.conscientiousness: Medium (6/10). Creative discipline for projects but struggles with paperwork and routine.
big_five.extraversion: Medium (6/10). Energized by small-group socializing and online interaction; prefers meaningful conversation to large parties.
big_five.agreeableness: High (7/10). Cooperative, empathetic and tends to assume goodwill, but can be firm about personal boundaries when needed.
big_five.neuroticism: Medium-High (6.5/10). Prone to anxiety around finances, academic performance, and social acceptance; uses creativity as an outlet.

interests: Short-form documentary storytelling (3–10 minute pieces) focusing on neighborhood businesses and street food vendors.
International pop and Afrobeats; playlists that mix Tems, Burna Boy, Koffee, Billie Eilish, and BTS.
Streaming serialized dramas and variety shows on Netflix and local streaming platforms.
Watching football (soccer) casually — follows the English Premier League and supports Arsenal; also watches local league highlights.
Food exploration: street food markets, roadside suya, jollof rice with variations across West Africa.
Culinary experiments at home: attempting small fusion recipes (e.g., plantain tacos).
Vlogging and short-form video creation on Instagram Reels and TikTok.
Podcasts on culture, entrepreneurship, and queer/gender issues.
Graphic design and typography appreciation — likes clean type in thumbnails.
Second-hand fashion treasure-hunting at local markets and thrift shops.
Learning basics of camera techniques and lighting on YouTube tutorials.
Attending small local concerts and open-mic nights when affordable.
Memes and web culture; active in online communities for fans of K-dramas and Afrobeats.
Sustainable practices when convenient (re-using jars, buying from small vendors).
Watching and critiquing advertising — interested in how brands tell local stories.
Photography, especially candid street shots at sunset.
Using social media for activism: organizing small community drives or visibility days.
Board and card games with friends (Uno, Ludo, and sometimes Cards Against Humanity).
Participating in university clubs: creative media club and a discussion group on contemporary African literature.
Gardening on a small balcony planter — herbs like basil, thyme, and a scrawny pepper plant.
music: Favorite artists: Tems, Burna Boy, SZA, Koffee, Tyler, the Creator, Joeboy, Billie Eilish, J Hus, Rema, BTS.
Enjoys mixtapes that blend Afrobeats with R&B and lo-fi hip-hop.
Likes long playlists for studying: instrumental lo-fi or mellow Afrobeats remixes.
Prefers vinyl-simulated warmth in mixes when producing content; often uses EQ presets to mimic analog sound.
Attends small local gigs for emerging artists rather than big stadium shows.
Dislikes overly auto-tuned pop that feels sterile.
Enjoys learning song lyrics and occasionally covering songs for fun online.
Collects snippets of street music on their phone — market drummers, buskers.
Enjoys music discovery playlists and shares finds with close friends.
Has a soft spot for nostalgic 2000s R&B when decompressing.
tv_and_streaming: Regularly watches Netflix, YouTube, and a local streaming service for Nollywood films.
Follows short YouTube documentary channels and lifestyle vloggers from Lagos and Accra.
Enjoys K-dramas for their emotionally expressive storytelling; watches with friends.
Binge-watches investigative docuseries for production technique inspiration.
Prefers streaming on a tablet or laptop at home; occasionally on a phone during commute.
Uses subtitles frequently — watches English-language content with subtitles when studying language use.
Dislikes low-production-value videos with poor audio; values good sound more than flashy visuals.
sports: Casual football fan: watches select Premier League matches and local highlight reels.
Enjoys informal pick-up football games with neighbors on weekends.
Watches international tournaments when Nigeria is competing.
Follows athletes who are vocal about social issues and uses them as examples of platform responsibility.
food_and_restaurants: Loves jollof rice in its various regional permutations; debates with friends about the best local recipe.
Favorite street foods: suya (spiced grilled meat skewers), puff-puff, akara, and fried plantain.
Enjoys trying small international-cuisine pop-ups — Korean fried chicken, Turkish wraps, and sushi trucks.
Prefers casual, lively eateries rather than quiet fine dining.
Values a restaurant with good Wi-Fi and charging points for editing work.
Enjoys sharing plates with friends and sampling multiple dishes.
Likes drinks: zobo (hibiscus), ginger drink, iced coffee, and the occasional smoothie.
Dislikes over-sugared sodas and overly spicy dishes that obscure flavors.
social_media_and_tech: Primary platforms: Instagram, TikTok, YouTube, WhatsApp.
Uses a mid-range smartphone with reliable mobile data plan and a local SIM with two numbers (one for family, one for clients).
Prefers quick, authentic content rather than overproduced ads.
Follows creators who discuss mental health and gender diversity in Africa.
Knows how to use basic editing on CapCut and InShot; learning Premiere Pro via tutorials.
Uses cloud backup (Google Drive) and a small external hard drive for important footage.
hobbies: Short-form documentary projects: filming one-minute portraits of local artisans.
Cooking small fusion recipes and testing them on close friends.
Street photography at golden hour sessions.
Collecting second-hand t-shirts and customizing them.
Attending community clean-ups or small activism events.
Reading contemporary African fiction and essays.
Writing micro-essays and captions for social posts.
Learning basic guitar chords from online lessons.
Editing video on public laptops when electricity is out at home.
Learning Yoruba proverbs and incorporating them into scripts.
likes: Late afternoons with soft sunlight for filming.
People who ask thoughtful questions rather than performative 'likes.'
Affordable cafés with good plugs and friendly staff.
Friends who can give honest creative feedback.
Finding a perfect clip where audio and image sync beautifully.
Local markets with colorful textiles and friendly traders.
Open conversations about gender and identity with trusted peers.
Small rituals: boiling strong tea before a study session.
Affordable second-hand camera lenses to practice with.
Community gatherings that celebrate local culture.
dislikes: Performative allyship online without follow-up action.
Clients who expect professional results without fair pay.
Long bureaucratic forms without accessible guidance.
Predatory microloan apps with hidden fees.
Constant power outages that interrupt editing.
People who police language and pronouns aggressively rather than politely correcting.
Crowded spaces where pickpocketing is likely.
Content that erases local nuance for global clicks.

beliefs: Education is a tool for mobility but should not erase cultural roots.
Representation matters: seeing gender diverse people in media reduces stigma.
Digital skills are essential for modern job prospects in Lagos.
Small local businesses are the backbone of neighborhood economies.
Creative work can be a viable livelihood if approached with business discipline.
Access to reliable electricity and internet is a social equity issue.
Mental health is real and deserves accessible community-level care.
Young people should have a stronger voice in local politics.
Religion and spirituality can coexist with queer identities; context matters for personal reconciliation.
Language variety (Pidgin, Yoruba, English) is an asset, not a deficiency.
International pop culture is useful for inspiration but local stories should lead.
There should be more affordable arts education in public schools.
Storytelling is a way to preserve memory and counter erasure.
Voting matters, but political candidates must be held accountable after elections.
Entrepreneurship without basic business skills often leads to burnout.
Artists should be fairly compensated and not exploited for 'exposure.'
Gendered expectations in families can be limiting and should be negotiable.
Climate change impacts urban life (flooding, heat) and local planning must adapt.
Platforms have responsibility to moderate hate but also protect free expression.
Youth activism should be intersectional: linking labor, gender, environment, and education.
Access to contraception and reproductive information is important for youth empowerment.
Peer networks are often more practical than distant institutions in crises.
Travel broadens perspective but doesn't inherently make someone better or wiser.
Community knowledge-holders (market elders, artisans) deserve recognition in media.
Financial literacy should be taught in secondary schools.
Not everyone needs to leave Nigeria to be successful; local opportunities can be built.
Online fame is volatile; building diversified income streams is safer.
Self-care routines are necessary but often commodified; simple practices suffice.
Gender identity is personal and evolves; people should be allowed space to explore.
Public spaces should be safer for women and gender diverse people at night.
Peer pressure to follow trends can be creatively stifling; discerning adaptation is better.
Formal institutions are useful but often slow; combine them with grassroots action.
Sharing content responsibly matters: consent and dignity for people filmed on the street.
Critical thinking and media literacy reduce the spread of harmful rumors and scams.
Mentorship accelerates growth; experienced creators have a responsibility to pass on knowledge.
Authenticity can be cultivated; it's not just spontaneous performance.
skills: Smartphone filmmaking: framing, natural light use, basic audio capture with earbuds or cheap lavalier mics.
Short-form video editing in CapCut and InShot; basic timeline editing and transitions.
Basic Premiere Pro and DaVinci Resolve familiarity from online tutorials (intermediate beginner).
Social media content strategy: scheduling, caption writing, simple analytics interpretation.
Photography fundamentals: composition, golden hour awareness, candid portraiture.
Basic graphic design with Canva: creating thumbnails and simple overlays.
Bilingual communication: fluent in English and Yoruba; conversational Nigerian Pidgin.
Public speaking and narration for short documentary voiceovers.
Basic budgeting for freelance gigs and simple invoicing via mobile banking.
Client negotiation: setting deliverables, timelines, and modest pricing.
Community organizing: coordinating small campus events and volunteer drives.
Time management for creative cycles: chunking editing tasks into focused sessions.
Simple troubleshooting of common tech issues: storage cleanup, app reinstalls, file format conversion.
Quick recipe development and informal food styling for social posts.
Soft skills: active listening, empathetic interviewing, and workshop facilitation for peers.

general: Checks phone first thing after waking and last thing before sleeping; uses it as a primary tool for work and social life.
Tends to film short clips of daily life and voice notes to capture creative ideas.
Uses humor and pop-culture references to defuse awkward conversations.
Often reorganizes camera folders and labels clips by project to stay organized creatively.
Prefers in-person feedback sessions with one or two trusted peers rather than public critique.
Has a small ritual before editing: strong tea, headphones on, playlist set to lo-fi or mellow Afrobeats.
Saves receipts and small cash in a 'project envelope' for client-related expenses.
Walks home after evening shifts at nearby cafés when the weather is good; avoids bad-lit shortcuts.
Is protective of close friends and acts as an informal mediator in group conflicts.
Can get into marathon editing sessions that stretch into the night when a deadline approaches.

morning: Wakes around 6:30–7:30 AM on weekdays (varies with deadlines and late-night editing).
Checks WhatsApp groups for university announcements and freelance client messages.
Makes strong tea or instant coffee; sometimes shares a quick breakfast with a sibling.
Reviews a short to-do list for classes and any editing tasks.
Leaves early to avoid peak traffic, often listening to an educational podcast during the commute.
workday: Attends lectures and tutorials; takes notes on a tablet or notebook with a focus on project ideas.
Spends midday editing on campus computers or in a café with reliable power.
Responds to client DMs and schedules posts during breaks.
Eats street food or a small campus meal; often shares with friends.
Practices short interview techniques by asking peers quick questions for sample clips.
evening: Edits footage, exports short versions for client review, and makes minor adjustments after feedback.
Chats with friends on voice notes; sometimes joins an online watch party for a series episode.
Reviews budget and upcoming commitments; may take a short walk to clear the head.
Goes to bed around 11:30 PM–1:00 AM, later during heavy workload periods.
weekend: Works on bigger personal projects: filming neighborhood stories, visiting markets for b-roll.
Attends a small gig, campus event, or community meeting.
Helps family with errands or visits relatives in nearby neighborhoods.
Schedules downtime: a long phone call with a best friend or a short trip to a nearby beach on rare occasions.

physical: Generally healthy and active; slim build from walking and frequent short football games.
Mild seasonal allergic rhinitis (hay-fever) that flares during dusty harmattan months.
Occasional headaches when editing for long stretches without breaks or during power-surge-related stress.
No major chronic illnesses; up-to-date on basic childhood vaccinations. Has had routine treatment for malaria episodes in the past.
Vision mildly short-sighted; uses prescription glasses for long-form reading but often squints when editing if glasses misplaced.
mental: Mild to moderate anxiety linked to inconsistent income, academic performance, and social expectations.
Uses creative work and peer support as primary coping strategies.
Practices informal self-care: short walks, playlists, and periodic social media breaks.
Open to counseling but has not regularly attended therapy due to cost and limited local availability.
Occasional sleep disruption during intense project deadlines.
sexual_and_reproductive: Sexually active in consensual relationships; practices safer sex and prefers open conversations about consent with partners.
Aware of STI testing but access can be awkward; would go to a discreet clinic if needed.
Believes in accessible reproductive health information for young people.
substance_use: Occasional alcohol consumption in social settings (infrequent and moderate).
Does not use hard drugs; occasionally smokes shisha or vapes socially but is trying to cut back.
Relies on caffeine during editing sprints.
health.medical_history_notes: No surgeries or hospitalizations beyond common childhood procedures and malaria treatment. No current medications besides occasional antihistamines for allergies.

relationships.name: Halima Ajani
relationships.description: Early 40s, market trader who sells fabrics. Practical and hardworking. Supportive but worried about Riley's unstable income; giggles when Riley uses new slang incorrectly. Their relationship is close; Riley helps with small tasks and brings edited photos of the stall to post on Halima's social page.

relationships.name: Bimbo Ajani
relationships.description: Lives in the same neighborhood, works as a nurse in a private clinic. Pragmatic, offers advice about time management and finances. Acts as occasional emergency fund when Riley's phone credit runs out.

relationships.name: Tunde
relationships.description: A fellow student who shoots music videos; they trade favors — Tunde handles on-camera production when Riley directs, and Riley edits Tunde’s footage. They share an informal co-op of ideas and sometimes split small payments.

relationships.name: Amina
relationships.description: Met on campus; 19, studying Sociology. They have a tender and experimental relationship that includes shared readings, impromptu film nights, and conversations about gender identity. Both negotiate boundaries and prefer honest communication.

relationships.name: Media Club peers
relationships.description: Group of 6–8 students who meet weekly for critique sessions. They provide feedback, sometimes pool small funds for kit rentals, and collaborate on campus projects.

relationships.name: Mentor (Ms. Okonkwo)
relationships.description: A mid-thirties freelance documentarian who ran a weekend workshop Riley attended; gives occasional counsel, portfolio notes, and helps with references for small grants.

relationships.name: Clients (two cafés and one clothing seller)
relationships.description: Small-business owners who value Riley's aesthetic and community credibility; payments are periodic and sometimes delayed, which creates financial strain.

relationships.name: Distant relatives
relationships.description: Several aunt/uncle figures who periodically ask about marriage prospects and career stability; typical intergenerational expectations create gentle tension with Riley's exploration of identity and career choices.

other_facts: Given name Riley is a family compromise: a parent's favorite western name combined with Ajani, a Yoruba name meaning 'he fights for his place', reflecting mixed cultural influences in the family.
Grew up in a bustling urban compound where many neighbors are like extended family; learned early to be streetwise.
First filmed a five-minute neighborhood vendor profile at age 15 for a school project and felt 'seen' when it circulated among relatives on WhatsApp.
Has 2,400 followers across Instagram and TikTok combined, mostly local peers and a handful of small international fans who appreciated a short mini-documentary.
Keeps a hard drive with early, messy edits and occasionally revisits older projects to see growth.
Was awarded a small campus grant to buy a tripod for a documentary project about Lagos bus drivers.
Has a trusted old compact camera borrowed from an uncle; treats it carefully and brings it for market shoots.
Once filmed a short piece that got shared by a local online journal, bringing a spike in followers and two small paid requests.
Learned basic editing through a free 12-hour YouTube crash course and several peer-led workshops.
Has a persistent fear of losing footage to a corrupted memory card; hence multiple backups and careful file naming.
Remembers a formative trip to a coastal town at age 12 where they fell in love with the sound of fishermen singing; uses that memory in narration scripts.
Their favorite childhood book was a collection of Yoruba folktales read aloud by their grandmother, who taught Riley many proverbs.
Volunteered at a local NGO last year to help run social-media campaigns for a youth literacy program.
Has a small balcony herb garden that serves as a calming microproject and occasional b-roll backdrop.
Is learning to repair a basic laptop battery connector from a neighborhood repair technician to save costs.
Kept a physical journal through secondary school; recent notes are mixed: project ideas, budget lists, and lists of people to interview.
Is comfortable but discreet about being non-binary among close friends; at family gatherings uses more traditional gendered language to avoid friction but gently corrects when safe.
Learned cooking skills primarily from their mother and older sister; can prepare a mean jollof with perfectly fried plantain.
Has a photographic memory for faces — good at remembering people interviewed once and calling them back later for follow-ups.
Once organized a small campus screening that led to a productive debate about representation in student media.
Had a minor dispute with a café client about late payment; resolved it through a frank in-person conversation mediated by a mutual acquaintance.
Uses a nicknamed power bank 'Shoe-Box Charger' that has been repaired twice and is considered a cherished piece of kit.
Stays connected to a rotating circle of three best friends who act as sounding boards for major creative decisions.
Has a recurring dream of editing a full-length documentary and screening it at a small festival in Accra or Lagos.
Collects short, handwritten recipes from different markets and keeps them in a battered notebook that doubles as inspiration for food videos.
Learned basic electrical safety after a scary moment when the laptop tripped a power surge; now uses surge protectors religiously.
Has a small superstition: taps the wooden table three times before starting audio recording to 'clear the air' — a ritual borrowed from a mentor.
Won a school award for 'Best Visual Presentation' in senior year for a multimedia essay on urban migration.
Is often the person friends call late at night to help mediate interpersonal issues — Riley listens deeply but sometimes ends up emotionally drained.
Remembers precisely the smell of their grandmother's kitchen and uses sensory detail like that in voiceover drafts.
Has an old playlist titled 'Editing Mood — Golden Hour' that they use as an anchor to get into the right working tempo.
Was once pickpocketed on a crowded bus; now keeps valuables in inner pockets and travels with a trusted friend when possible.
Has a small tattoo (symbolic, discreet) that signifies resilience; got it at 17 with close friends in a safe, informal setting.
Is interested in the idea of a community-funded camera co-op so students can borrow higher-end gear affordably.
Keeps a folder of 'people to interview' with notes on where they work and why their story matters.
Believes a single well-made five-minute film can change a person's perspective if distributed thoughtfully; uses that belief to prioritize clarity over flashy effects.
Has been approached about sponsored content but declines brands that do not align with community values.
Has a small ritual of gifting printed Polaroid-like photos to the subjects of their short films as a thank-you.
Is learning basic legal awareness about consent and releases for people filmed in public, discussing templates with their media club.
Knows how to haggle politely in markets and uses that skill when renting equipment or buying props.
Keeps an emergency contact list pinned in a phone case: mom, sister, mentor, and one close friend. Always informs someone when shooting late in unfamiliar areas.
Has a vivid memory of the first time they used a stabilizer — felt it professionalized their shots and marked a turning point in self-confidence.
Occasionally experiences imposter syndrome after scrolling through polished portfolios online but counters it by re-watching early praise messages from mentors.
Is building a slow, intentional archive of local rhythms (market calls, artisan hammerbeats, bus departures) for future use in documentaries.
